comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: London Gazette, 2 November 1918, p. 12954: “War Office, 2nd November, 1918. […] “ROYAL ARMY MEDICAL CORPS. Capt. (actg. Maj.) R. Proudfoot, M.D., relinquishes his actg. rank on ceasing to be specially empld. 28th June 1918. Lt.-Col. E. J. Lawless, from T.F. Res., to be Lt.-Col., with precedence from 19th Sept. 1914. 18th Oct. 1918. Lt.-Col. E. M. Callender, M.D., from Gen. Hospital, to be Lt.-Col., with precedence from 13th Mar. 1912. 3rd Nov. 1918. Capt. A. McGillivray, M.B., to be Maj. 5th, Oct. 1918. Capt. J. E. Adams, M.B., F.R.C.S., is seconded for service overseas. 31st Oct. 1918. Lt. R. McKenzie to be Capt. 28th Feb. 1918.” www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/30988/supplements/12954/ London Gazette, 26 January 1923, p. 612: “War Office, 26th January, 1923. […] ROYAL ARMY MEDICAL CORPS. […] The undermentioned Offrs. relinquish their commns., 30th Sept. 1921, under A.O. 166/21, as amended by A.O. 332/21. And retain their rank except where otherwise stated: -- […] Capt. J. E. Adams, M.B., F.R.C.S.” www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/32790/pages/612/

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: A surgeon named J. E. Adams also features in the St. Thomas's Hospital Reports from the early 1920s, where "J. E. Adams, M.B., MS., London, F. R.C.S." is described as one of the editors (Vol. XLVI, 1924, t.p. +p. 45), also in giving classes in advanced operative surgery (Vol. XLVI, 1924, p. 232). His address in the list of subscribers is given as: "19 Harley Street, W.1" archive.org/details/reportssth46sainuoft archive.org/details/reportssth47sainuoft He also features as a subscriber in an earlier edition (Vol. XLIV, 1918, p. iii), where his address is given as "40 Devonshire Place, W," and where he is described as a specialist in the diseases of children (p. 13) archive.org/details/reportssth44sainuoft

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: There is a short biography of Joseph Ebenezer Adams (1878 - 1926) available on the Royal College of Surgeons website: livesonline.rcseng.ac.uk/biogs/E000645b.htm This states that "during the war he acted with the rank of captain on the à la suite staff of the Fifth London General Hospital (the St Thomas's unit), and at King George's Hospital." There is also a very interesting obituary published in the British Medical Journal in 1927 that points out that Mr Adams had been prevented from serving overseas due to a disability, and that this had been a very real grief to him. The condition (a congenital diaphragmatic hernia) contributed to his early death at the age of 48. The photograph is definitely of the same person (and the obituary is well worth a read). Br Med J 1927;1:44.1 doi: dx.doi.org/10.1136/bmj.1.3443.44 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2453826/?page=1 As a surgeon, he published a book (The diagnosis and treatment of acute abdominal diseases, 2nd ed., 1923, the revised version of a book first published by Adams and a colleague in 1913) and number of research articles, including several on appendicitis and one in the BMJ (1925) on abdominal crises in children. This last describes his affiliations as: Senior Surgeon at East London Hospital for Children and Surgeon to St Thomas's Hospital: europepmc.org/articles/PMC2227879/pdf/brmedj05738-0001.pdf

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: A photograph his grave in Chislehurst (and that of his wife, Muriel Emma) is available at: billiongraves.com/pages/record/JOSEPHEBENEZERADAMS/5793182

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Joseph Ebenezer Adams birth recorded 1st qr 1878 in Pancras Joseph E Adams marriage recorded 4th qr 1913 to Muriel E Webb in Bromley Joseph E Adams death recorded 4th qr 1926 age 48 in Maidenhead There are too many Adams / Webb births in any one year to determine any offspring of this couple. www.freebmd.org.uk
